1.name: Hydrogen
1.use: Water, stars, organic compounds, rocket fuel

2.name: Helium
2.sc: Inert gas, lowest boiling point of all elements

5.name: Boron
5.sc: Hard, brittle, forms strong covalent bonds

6.name: Carbon
6.use: Basis of all organic life, fuels, diamonds, graphite
6.sc: Exists in multiple allotropes, unique bonding properties

7.name: Nitrogen
7.sc: Inert at room temperature, essential for life

8.name: Oxygen
8.sc: Highly reactive, essential for combustion and life

10.name: Neon
10.sc: Inert gas, produces orange-red glow in discharge tubes

11.name: Sodium
11.sc: Highly reactive, soft metal, reacts violently with water

12.name: Magnesium
12.sc: Burns with a bright white flame

14.name: Silicon
14.sc: Second most abundant element in Earth's crust

15.name: Phosphorus
15.use: Fertilizers, detergents, matches, bones (in living organisms)
15.sc: Glows in the dark (white phosphorus), highly reactive forms

16.name: Sulfur
16.use: Sulfuric acid, fertilizers, gunpowder, vulcanization of rubber
16.sc: Distinctive odor, found in volcanic regions

18.name: Argon
18.sc: Most abundant noble gas in Earth's atmosphere

19.name: Potassium
19.use: Fertilizers, soap, essential nutrient for plants and animals
19.sc: Highly reactive, soft metal, reacts violently with water

21.name: Scandium
21.use: Lightweight alloys (aerospace, sports equipment), stadium lamps
21.sc: Relatively rare, similar properties to rare earth elements

22.name: Titanium
22.sc: Strongest lightweight metal, excellent corrosion resistance

23.name: Vanadium
23.sc: Increases strength and hardness of steel

26.name: Iron
26.sc: Most common element by mass in Earth, ferromagnetic

29.name: Copper
29.use: Electrical wiring, plumbing, coins, alloys (brass, bronze)

30.name: Zinc
30.use: Galvanizing steel, batteries, brass, dietary supplement

33.name: Arsenic
33.sc: Toxic, but also used in some medicines

34.name: Selenium
34.use: Photocells, solar cells, toners, dietary supplement
34.sc: Photosensitive, conducts electricity when exposed to light

35.name: Bromine
35.discoverer: Antoine Jérôme Balard, Carl Jacob Löwig
35.sc: Only nonmetal that is liquid at room temperature

36.name: Krypton
36.sc: Inert gas, used in high-performance lighting

37.name: Rubidium
37.sc: Highly reactive, ignites spontaneously in air

38.name: Strontium
38.sc: Burns with a brilliant red flame

39.name: Yttrium
39.use: Yttrium iron garnet (microwave filters), LEDs, superconductors
39.sc: Rare earth element, used in various technologies

40.name: Zirconium
40.sc: Excellent corrosion resistance, very high melting point

42.name: Molybdenum
42.use: Steel alloys, catalysts, lubricants, high-temperature applications
42.sc: High melting point, essential trace element

43.name: Technetium
43.sc: Lightest element with no stable isotopes (radioactive)

47.name: Silver
47.sc: Best electrical and thermal conductor of all metals

49.name: Indium
49.sc: Very soft, ductile, transparent when coated thinly

51.name: Antimony
51.sc: Has distinct metallic and nonmetallic forms

53.name: Iodine
53.sc: Sublimes directly from solid to gas, essential nutrient

54.name: Xenon
54.sc: Inert gas, forms some compounds with fluorine and oxygen

55.name: Cesium
55.use: Atomic clocks, photoelectric cells, drilling fluids
55.sc: Most reactive alkali metal, liquid near room temp

58.name: Cerium
58.discoverer: Jöns Jacob Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger, Martin Heinrich Klaproth
58.use: Catalytic converters, flint (for lighters), glass polishing

60.name: Neodymium
60.use: Strong magnets (NdFeB), laser materials, purple glass

61.name: Promethium
61.discoverer: Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Charles D. Coryell

62.name: Samarium
62.use: Magnets, carbon arc lighting, nuclear reactor control rods

63.name: Europium
63.use: Red and blue phosphors in TVs and monitors, superconductors

64.name: Gadolinium
64.use: MRI contrast agents, neutron absorption (nuclear reactors), magnets
64.sc: High magnetic moment, used in medical imaging

65.name: Terbium
65.sc: Used in energy-efficient lighting and "green" lasers

66.name: Dysprosium
66.use: Magnets, laser materials, nuclear reactor control rods

67.name: Holmium
67.sc: Highest magnetic moment of any natural element

68.name: Erbium
68.use: Optical fibers, laser materials, pink glass

69.name: Thulium
69.sc: Least abundant rare earth element after promethium

70.name: Ytterbium
70.use: Fiber lasers, smart materials, steel alloys

71.name: Lutetium
71.discoverer: Georges Urbain, Carl Auer von Welsbach
71.sc: Last element in the lanthanide series, very dense

72.name: Hafnium
72.use: Nuclear reactor control rods, superalloys, semiconductors
72.sc: Good neutron absorber, chemically similar to zirconium

73.name: Tantalum
73.use: Capacitors (electronics), surgical implants, high-temperature furnace parts
73.sc: High corrosion resistance, very high melting point

74.name: Tungsten
74.use: Filaments (light bulbs), high-speed steel, heavy-metal alloys
74.sc: Highest melting point of all elements

75.name: Rhenium
75.discoverer: Walter Noddack, Ida Noddack, Otto Berg
75.sc: One of the densest elements, very rare

76.name: Osmium
76.use: Pen tips, electrical contacts, surgical implants
76.sc: Densest naturally occurring element, very hard and brittle

77.name: Iridium
77.use: Spark plugs, crucibles, electrical contacts, fountain pen nibs
77.sc: Most corrosion-resistant metal, used as a marker for the K-Pg boundary

78.name: Platinum
78.discoverer: Antonio de Ulloa (rediscovered by Charles Wood)
78.use: Catalytic converters, jewelry, laboratory equipment, anticancer drugs

79.name: Gold
79.sc: Highly malleable and ductile, corrosion-resistant, excellent conductor

80.name: Mercury
80.sc: Only metal that is liquid at room temperature, highly toxic

81.name: Thallium
81.sc: Highly toxic, soft, low melting point

83.name: Bismuth
83.sc: Only non-radioactive heavy metal with atomic number > 82

85.name: Astatine
85.discoverer: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè
85.sc: Rarest naturally occurring element, highly radioactive

87.name: Francium
87.sc: Most reactive alkali metal, highly radioactive, extremely rare

88.name: Radium
88.sc: Highly radioactive, glows in the dark (due to radiation)

90.name: Thorium
90.sc: Naturally occurring radioactive element, alternative nuclear fuel

91.name: Protactinium
91.discoverer: Kasimir Fajans, O. H. Göhring, Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner
91.sc: Highly radioactive and toxic, very rare

92.name: Uranium
92.sc: Fissile, primary fuel for nuclear power and weapons

94.name: Plutonium
94.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Edwin McMillan, Joseph W. Kennedy, Arthur C. Wahl
94.sc: Highly radioactive, very toxic, complex metallurgy

95.name: Americium
95.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso
95.sc: Radioactive, used in common household smoke detectors

96.name: Curium
96.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso

97.name: Berkelium
97.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, Albert Ghiorso

98.name: Californium
98.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, Kenneth Street Jr., Albert Ghiorso
98.sc: Strong neutron emitter, very rare and expensive

99.name: Einsteinium
99.sc: Discovered in debris from the first hydrogen bomb test

102.name: Nobelium
102.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (Dubna), Albert Ghiorso et al. (Berkeley)

104.name: Rutherfordium
104.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (Dubna), Albert Ghiorso et al. (Berkeley)

105.name: Dubnium
105.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (Dubna), Albert Ghiorso et al. (Berkeley)

108.name: Hassium
108.sc: Named after the German state of Hesse

115.name: Moscovium
115.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (Dubna), Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

116.name: Livermorium
116.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (Dubna), Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
116.sc: Named after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

117.name: Tennessine
117.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (Dubna), Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Vanderbilt University, University of Tennessee

118.name: Oganesson
118.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (Dubna), Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
